instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.BUTTON_DISABLE: What is BUTTON_DISABLE? BUTTON_DISABLE disables the trackpad when SMC_LID is below 0.5v and the system believes the lid is closed. .
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a MacBook Pro with non-functioning trackpad and keyboard. Tested new keyboard / trackpad and still not working. The keyboard (new and old) will only work if I hold the key a little bit.

I checked <SIGNAL>WS_KBD</SIGNAL> and all of them are fluctuating a lot between 0.5 to 3 volts. Never consistent. Connector looks clean and the <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> area looks clean. Has the controller failed? Should I check elsewhere? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_PSOC</SIGNAL> pin 49 and 22 of <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is 3.3 volts.

Please advise, thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R5701</RESISTOR>/02/04.
Be sure to have <SIGNAL>TPAD_VBUS_EN</SIGNAL> present.
Also check <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL>.

Do you get correct powers at J5700?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Here are the readings.

<RESISTOR>R5701</RESISTOR> - fluctuates 0.5 - 3 volts
<RESISTOR>R5702</RESISTOR> - 0.00 - 0.02 cycles
<RESISTOR>R5704</RESISTOR> - 3.3 volts

<SIGNAL>TPAD_VBUS_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> - 0 volts

Going to see what's the issue with <RESISTOR>R5701</RESISTOR>/02

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
If both resistors have good ohm value, change <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>.
There is USB line, complementary voltages; do nor expect 3V on both data lines.

Problems with other USB ports/devices will point to <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Okay, I will replace <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. Must I get it from the same board number? Are there any other boards I can take it off of?

I noticed <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> have same
CY8C24794
337S2983
MLF
<SIGNAL>SYM_VER2</SIGNAL>

Does this mean they have similar firmware?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
I cannot confirm 100%.
If the swap works between good boards, then equivalency is confirmed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Okay, so I replaced <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> (twice) and exact same result. <SIGNAL>WS_KBD</SIGNAL> fluctuating but it seems to be better? 1.5 - 3 volts Maybe a coincidence. I then replaced <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> and still not working.

<SIGNAL>Z2_SCLK</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>Z2_CLKIN</SIGNAL> fluctuating 0.5 -1.5 volts.

Seems like there is only so many places to look, but I can't seem to find it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message: Oh yes, I meant to say all <SIGNAL>WS_KBDX</SIGNAL> signals are fluctuating same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message: All the power rails in that page are steady?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
The power rails for the keyboard is steady.

Here's something odd I found. When I disconnect the trackpad flex cable, the <SIGNAL>WS_KBDX</SIGNAL> signals are steady and the keyboard is very responsive. As soon as I reconnect the trackpad + flex cable, it jumps up and down. When I leave the trackpad flex connected and disconnect the actual trackpad from the flex cable, the <SIGNAL>WS_KBDX</SIGNAL> signals are steady. Tried new trackpad + new flex cable.

Looks like I'll need to order a trackpad connector and try that out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Be aware of new flex from China; some people complained, needed to try 2-3 untill find good one.

Test continuity from MLB to trackpad board, when flex is connected.
You can also compare diode mode readings on the connector (TP connected), with a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Keyboard / Trackpad Not Functioning
threads.message:
Okay, so I did more tests and then found that <SIGNAL>WS_KBDX</SIGNAL> signals + pin 2 / 9 of the TP connector (<SIGNAL>Z2_CLKIN</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>Z2_SCLK</SIGNAL>) were fluctuating regardless of whether or not TP is connected. I was convinced that maybe something was in the TP connector (because why all of a sudden is it acting like this after reconnecting flex cable several times?) so I ended up removing it.

Now that it has been removed, it's still fluctuating with no keyboard connected, no TP connected (obviously) and now I have a board with no TP connector! I am having some difficult sourcing out the part online. Now everything is pointing back to a controller issue which I replaced 3-4 times already.
